title: having a laugh 10 top office themed pranks for april
story: April Fools Day prankApril Fool#s Day FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueApril Fools Day prankAmy CochraneTwitterEmailApril   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailApril Fools’ Day is celebrated in cultures around the world traditionally on the first day of that month, which falls on Friday.Though its origins remain a mystery, many businesses, brands and media outlets take the opportunity to have a little fun with their customers and readers.Coca-Cola famously promoted a new avocado-flavoured drink one year, and Burger King advertised a Left-Handed Whopper, which fooled scores of customers who requested the fake burger.But the question arises year on year: how far is too far with your pranks With more of us back in the office now following lockdown, tomorrow could be a good opportunity to have a bit of fun with colleagues. But to ensure HR doesn’t come calling, here are  ways to celebrate the day without getting in trouble.: Cardboard cutoutsCardboard cutouts of celebrities — or even people you know — always manage to bring a laugh out of anyone. You can hide these behind doorways or in windows to give a shock to your colleagues. If you want to go the extra mile, why not make ones of yourself and strategically place them around the office.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up : Balloon roomWhile less infuriating than a glitter bomb, it is far easier to clean up. Filling up the conference room with balloons is a harmless and colourful prank that people can enjoy from the spectacle and effort alone.: Family swapIf you have some photo-editing skills and are in for a long-haul prank, then consider copying and Photoshopping your co-worker’s desk photos. Swap out their loved ones for one of your favourite cartoon or TV characters and see how long it takes them to notice.: Did you get my memo A classic in every sense of the word. Sticking Post-it notes all over someone’s workspace is as time-consuming as it is funny. You don’t have to stop there. You can even go as far as to cover their car in Post-it notes and see how long it takes for them to get rid of them all.: Flip the screenThe fastest prank you can do on this list, and possibly one of the longest to fixyour ‘mark’ is not computer savvy. Go to display settings and flip the computer screen horizontally so that everything is upside down. Watch and laugh as they struggle to get things back to some sort of normality.: Mouse trapAnother old school prank guaranteed to produce lots of laughs. Tape over the sensor on your co-worker’s mouse and watch as they try and figure out why their computer refuses to work.: Air hornAttaching an air horn underneath a chair or behind a door is a timeless prank. There really is nothing more satisfying or as basic as a jump scare. Nobody said April Fools’ pranks had to be high art.: He’s behind youWhile working from home, Zoom backgrounds did a lot of heavy lting in the prank department. The most creative fun you can have is to turn your remote background into a video. It can be anything from your doppelganger walking into the room, or a mysterious figure leering in the doorway.: Hot micThere’s nothing more anxiety-inducing than wonderingyour microphone is on during a meeting. One prank would be to stage this situation and make your co-workers believe that you think you’re on mute. See how long it takes for your co-workers to interrupt you and others in your household from saying some really embarrassing things.: That’s a wrapGt wrap your prank this year by wrapping all of your co-worker’s belongings in wrapping paper. It’s always the larks with the most effort put into them which are the most satisfying. So don’t skimp out on the attention to detail. title: how to spot the northern lights over northern ireland tonight
story: The Northern Lights seen over Dunluce Castle in . Photo by Jason Murphy. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueThe Northern Lights seen over Dunluce Castle in . Photo by Jason Murphy.Allan PrestonTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailNorthern Ireland could be one of the best places to catch an appearance of the Northern Lights this evening.The British Geological Survey have said there is now an increased chance of seeing the aurora phenomenon on Thursday evening and Friday across the UK, with those in Scotland, northern England and Northern Ireland likely to have the best opportunities.The BGS say it is easier to spot the Aurora Borealis than you might think, but it does depend on having the right conditions of having clear and dark skies.Geomagnetic Disturbance Alertth MarchBritish Geological Survey Assuming clear dark skies, there is an increased chance of seeing the aurora on st March and April st. In the UK, those in Scotland, northern England and Northern Ireland may have the best opportunities. pic psfZg— British Geological SurveyMarch , According to the BGS, the aurora is caused when there large explosions take place on the surface of the sun.This sends huge amounts of charged particles out into space, which sometimes travel towards Earth where they are captured by the magnetic field and guided towards the geomagnetic polar regions.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Read MoreNorthern Ireland weather: Cold snap set for awith snow showers possibleOn their way down they are slowed by Earth’s atmosphere which acts as a shield.When the charged particles collide with gas molecules in the atmosphere, the energy released manests in bright colours.The “auroral ovals” are most often seen in northern areas like Scandinavia, Greenland, Alaska, Canada and Russia as well as southern ovals covering the Antarctic regionsWhen there is increased geomagnetic activity, the ovals widen and spread meaning it can be possible to see them further south in the UK.Speaking to the Belfast , Met Office meteorologist Sarah Kent said sky watchers in Northern Ireland would still need a good amount of luck to catch the perfect moment.“If people are feeling lucky, they should go out and wrap themselves up. Tonight we are still looking at a mixture of showers and clear spells,” she said.Initially,you’re near the north coast that’s where you’re most likely to encounter the showers and some cloudier skies.“However, the further south you are it’s more likely you’ll get some clear spells. It’s certainly worth a shotpeople are going out this evening around -pm.”Conditions for catching the Northern Lights will also be more dficult in urban areas like Belfast.You do need the clear skies, so ideally you would want the northern horizon which is clear from light pollution.You could still head out to the north coast, and while likely to get a few showers in between them it’s where you’re going to get the darkest horizon.It’s a little bit of a Catch  there. I’m sure there will be some stunning photos but people will really need to be lucky.”Most ReadSDLP MP Claire Hanna’s ‘shock’ over proposal by Sinn Fein to abolish her South Belfast seatHaving a laugh:  top office-themed pranks for April Fool’s DayHow to spot the Northern Lights over Northern Ireland tonightRoy Reynolds: Co Antrim murder victim suffered ‘barbaric injuries’, court told‘My baby would still be aliveI’d got proper care at Lagan Valley Hospital’: Grieving mum speaks outTop Videos programme, which celebrates its th anniversary this year. story: Stock Image FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueStock ImageApril   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailCommuters facing the Friday rush hour are warned to expect disruption on the M eastbound road at the Lisburn junction in Antrim after large bags of salt and stone fell onto the road.The PSNI said there are currently delays as a result of the incident and advised anyone driving in the area to seek an alternative routethey can.Meanwhile, motorists are advised that there are delays on the Westlink in Belfast in both directions due to broken down vehicles.Both sides of the Westlink are down to one lane near Clton Street Bridge with traffic moving slowly in the area.The PSNI said drivers should seek alternative routespossible.Follow below for live updates:A Twitter List by BelTelDaily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Most ReadSDLP MP Claire Hanna’s ‘shock’ over proposal by Sinn Fein to abolish her South Belfast seatHaving a laugh:  top office-themed pranks for April Fool’s DayHow to spot the Northern Lights over Northern Ireland tonightRoy Reynolds: Co Antrim murder victim suffered ‘barbaric injuries’, court told‘My baby would still be aliveI’d got proper care at Lagan Valley Hospital’: Grieving mum speaks outTop Videos programme, which celebrates its th anniversary this year. title: taoiseach did not think twice about visit to northern ireland after alert
story: Taoiseach Micheal Martin speaks to the media during his visit to Londonderry  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueTaoiseach Micheal Martin speaks to the media during his visit to Londonderry By Jonathan McCambridge, PAApril   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailTaoiseach Micheal Martin has said he did not think twice about coming to Northern Ireland a week after a security alert disrupted a visit to Belfast by Irish Foreign Affairs Minister Simon Coveney.Mr Martin said he was heartened by the cross-community condemnation of the alert at a peace event last week.He is visiting Londonderry where he is carrying out a number of engagements.He is due to deliver a speech to the Hume Foundation in the city’s Playhouse theatre later.Last Friday, Mr Coveney had to abandon a speech title: what sanctions could p and o ferries face for sacking 800 workers
story: PandO is facing a criminal investigation  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":truePandO is facing a criminal investigation By Helen William, PAApril   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThe kind of sanctions PO Ferries could face for sacking  workers without notice is still unclear, lawyers and trade unions have said.Criminal and civil investigations have been launched by the Insolvency Service into the circumstances surrounding PO’s decision to make the seafarers redundant on March .A legal duty for PO to hold consultations on the redundancies and whether the firm gave the Secretary of State due notice about its plans are among the areas that could be investigated.The Insolvency Service said that “as these are ongoing investigations, no further comment or information can be provided at this time”."data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming  .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_cfbe--d-c-eadf_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming  .ece AUTOCROP w Transport Committee and Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy Select Committee No one knows what sort of fine or the scale of the sanction the firm could face but what is clear is the company is “banged to rights” on its failure to consult, according to the TUC.PO Ferries chief executive Peter Hebblethwaite told a joint hearing of the Commons’ business and transport committees that his company broke the law by not consulting with trade unions before sacking workers.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up He has also said that all vessels involved were registered outside the UK and the relevant authorities in each case had been notied.Employment lawyer Anita North, of Simpson Millar, said: “They could be investigated for not notying the Secretary of State about the fact they were going to make the redundancies but there are provisions in the legislation which say that the requirement depends on what the obligations are of the port in the country that the ship is registered.“Since these ships are registered outside of Britain, the obligation therefore falls with the jurisdiction of where they were registered.”On whether directors could be held liable, she said: “It is not clear there has been any wrongdoing or any financial dishonesty.“There is no suggestion of actual director dishonesty to give grounds for a criminal investigation. It is immoral I think, but ultimately there are no laws to say you cannot dismiss your employees without notice.“There are laws to say you should consult before you do that andyou don’t employees can claim a protective award but there are no sanctions as such that can be taken against iniduals.”"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming b .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_cfbe--d-c-eadf_embedded FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueA demonstration against the dismissal of PandO workers takes place outside the Port of Liverpool The TUC said it sees the dismissal of the  seafarers as an attempt by PO Ferries to “bypass” employment laws as bosses have “sought to impose the changes rather than negotiate them”.The union organisation said the plan was to replace seafarers on union-negotiated wages with low-paid agency staff thanks to gaping holes in the minimum wage rules as they apply to overseas workers on non-UK flagged vessels.PO may be investigated for failing to noty the Government in time but it is dficult to find previous examples of employers who have been hit with a punitive fine, Ms North and the TUC said.Companies can also face having to pay affected workers maximum protective awards of  days’ pay.It is possible that PO may have simply priced in the potential cost of such an award in its offer to dismissed seafarers, the TUC suggested.Ms North added: “I think it is part of a director’s duties to think about the financial viability of the company and do everything it can to ensure it does not go under but that should not just be from a personal point of view – there should be more consideration of how the decision being taken by the board affects the employees and not just the balance sheet.”Most ReadSDLP MP Claire Hanna’s ‘shock’ title: election briefing from gerrymandering and an april fools wish list to northern irelands most unambiguous party
story: Current NI electoral boundariesJim Allister and his we Ruth FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueCurrent NI electoral boundariesApril   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailDouble standards on gerrymandering Sinn Fein raised more than a few eyebrows on Friday when it emerged the party is proposing to have the South Belfast constituency abolished in future elections. The SDLP#s MP for the area, Claire Hanna, who romped home in the last general election with some , votes, around , more than the nearest candidate — expressed her shock at the turn of events. The constituency is also larger than East and West Belfast and is the most erse of all NI#s electoral areas, ing MLAs from five dferent parties: SDLP, DUP, Alliance, Sinn Fein and Greens. There is a term for this move by Sinn Fein we are all too familiar with: gerrymandering.What is most curious about this move is that, back in , proposed changes to electoral boundaries here that would seemingly have favoured the DUP were branded “gerrymandering to placate” Northern Ireland#s largest unionist party by Sinn Fein. This criticism was not voiced by one Sinn Fein representative or party spokesperson at the time, but at least half a dozen, in what was essentially a media blitz in a bid to put a spanner in the proposals.What is even more curious is that press statements on Sinn Fein#s website referring to said gerrymandering have vanished. If you simply google “Sinn Fein on gerrymandering” and click on any of the ious links which previously directed to statements from Conor Murphy, Colm Gildernew, Francie Molloy and others on the Sinn Fein website, you are greeted with the following  error message, reading: “We#re sorry, but the page you requested could not be found on our servers. We may have recently moved, renamed, or deleted certain pages.”It seems, much like the party#s previous stance on Russia, they are simply trying to avoid accusations of double standards and prone to extreme stance-switching when it suits them.Read MoreSinn Fein defend proposals to redraw Belfast’s electoral boundariesAn April Fool’s wish listDaily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Ah, April Fool#s Day. Given the state of world at the minute — war in Europe, the cost of living crisis on the tail end of a pandemic that hasn#t gone away - I was hoping we would give it a rest this year, lest we cause more unneeded distress. One humorous political wish list, however, was posted on Twitter by human rights organisation Participation and the Practice of Rights , reading: “‘Stick your hostile environment’ — Givan tells UK Home Office. ‘Mackies will be % social’ — Hargey takes action on housing rights. ‘Our policies are the problem, not you’ — Swann promises counsellors in every GP practice.” We can but dream.NI#s most unambiguous partyAn interesting press statement was released by the TUV on Friday, which declared that the party#s designation on the ballot paper for May#s poll will read: ‘TUV — No Sea Border’.Explaining the move, TUV leader Jim Allister said: “Having led where others have followed we wish every voter to see the issue identied without ambiguity on the ballot paper. There will be no doubt as to what a vote for TUV means.”Now, the TUV have been accused of being many things, but ‘ambiguous’ is definitely not one of them. Anyone with even a slight grasp of Northern Ireland politics could probably predict the party’s stance on any given issue before Jim Allister’s party has voiced its opinion. title: sinn fein slammed for election launch at belfasts europa hotel which was repeatedly bombed by ira
story: Victims campaigner questions the choice of venue as Michelle O’Neill outlines her party’s stanceExpandExpandExpandPreviousNext" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseSpeech: Sinn Fein’s Michelle O’Neill addressing a party election event in Belfast. Credit :Sinn FeinPAThe aftermath of an IRA attack in May The Europa Hotel following a massive IRA bomb explosion in  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSpeech: Sinn Fein’s Michelle O’Neill addressing a party election event in Belfast. Credit :Sinn FeinGarrett HarganTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailA victims’ campaigner has questioned the use of the Europa Hotel as the setting for Sinn Fein’s election launch, saying it’s a venue the Provisional IRA “systematically bombed”.On Tuesday, Michelle O’Neill gave a speech at the Great Victoria Street hotel, which was bombed  times during the Troubles.She outlined Sinn Fein’s priorities ahead of the upcoming election including the cost of living crisis and “fiercely defending” the Good Friday Agreement.“The facts are that the balance of power at Stormont has shted irreversibly and political unionism must come to terms with the fact the world is moving on fast,” Ms O’Neill said.“So, while the DUP and the TUV are trying to take us backwards, our message is clear, we are only moving forward.”Commenting on the choice of venue, Kenny Donaldson, spokesman for Innocent Victims United said: Sinn Fein clearly don#t do irony, to bleat on about upholding democracy at the very venue which the Provisional IRA systematically attacked again and again, making it the most bombed hotel in Europe is brazen to say the least.However, due to the intensity of the Provisional IRA#s bombing campaign — and that of other terrorists, few hotel venues across Northern Ireland have come away unscathed by the Troubles.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up TUV South Belfast candidate Andrew Girvin said Sinn Fein’s campaign launch at the Europa was a “grotesque spectacle” given the setting.“Here we had the political wing of the terrorist organisation which repeatedly bombed the hotel in which they met daring to ponticate about democracy and respecting the will of the people.“There is nothing undemocratic about refusing to operate the Belfast Agreement structures which could foist a Sinn Fein First Minister upon Northern Ireland.“The choice of venue for this republican jamboree underscores the fact that no unionist should ever agree to take up the position of deputy to a Sinn Fein First Minister.“Yet just weeks out from the election both the DUP and UUP are dodging this vital question.Will they act as bridesmaid to Michelle O#Neill  Why is there reluctance to be open and honest with the public on this point ”The DUP#s Gordon Lyons said Sinn Fein#s election launch demonstrates their priority lies on holding a border poll rather than on helping families or rebuilding Northern Ireland’s economy.The party#s director of elections said: Sinn Fein#s rally was a show of strength for a border poll.“Whilst the DUP has a five-point plan to build a better future for Northern Ireland, Sinn Fein wants to win the election to implement their plan for a border poll.“There is a clear choice on offer to people whether they want a future focused on fixing our health system, tackling the cost of living crisis and replacing the protocol, or one fixated on a isive border poll.“When Michelle O#Neill talks about making history, we know it isn#t record levels of investment into our hospitals she is referring to. Now is not the time for ision and uncertainty.That is why this election is so important.Sinn Fein has been contacted for comment.Speaking at an election launch, Ms O’Neill said that Sinn Fein will defend but not renegotiate the Good Friday Agreement.The former Deputy First Minister said those who hanker for the past need to realise that there is no going back, only forward.Sinn Fein#s Stormont leader also described the DUP#s collapse of the Executive as political vandalism, although her own party also brought Stormont down in the same Assembly mandate.She said: When the Assembly, Executive and North South Ministerial Council were restored in January  it was with a shared commitment to deliver the public services, societal reforms and future that our people need and deserve.It was ambitious to form a five-party coalition Executive, but it was achieved, getting us back to genuine power-sharing, and thankfully so, because while everyone knew there would be challenges ahead, no one could have predicted that in only a matter of weeks that our Executive would be dealing with a global pandemic that would have such devastating impacts on every part of society, community and people#s lives and livelihoods.It is to the credit of all ministers from across the five parties that they responded and have worked with a unity of purpose, and unity of leadership for the past two years.This is what the public want to see more of — co-operation and delivery.Ms O#Neill added: Sinn Fein will be defending, not renegotiating the Good Friday Agreement now, or in the time ahead.Ms O#Neill said the May  election was the most important in a generation.Related topicsSinn FéinMichelle O#NeillIRACost of LivingTraditional Unionist VoiceGordon LyonsThe Executive OfficeMore On Sinn Credit: Brian Lawless PAMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThe UUP manesto has enough meat to show that the party is starting to think seriously about being a major player in the Executive once more, and enough bare bones to reveal that the process is incomplete.At , words, this document is serious in its scope and suffused with the liberal unionist tone of new leader Doug Beattie.But it is what this manesto does not say which reveals most: hard choices or unpopular proposals are either absent or presented in oblique terms — and that jars with Mr Beattie’s straight-talking style.Health is the first and the iest section — unsurprisingly, given that polling has shown Robin Swann to be Stormont’s most popular minister.The manesto indicates support for radical measures, saying that the pandemic has shown that both patients and medics are willing “to travel longer distancesit means receiving care and support in a more timely manner. It is essential that the opportunities currently before us are not lost”.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Read MoreNo united Ireland for generations to come, UUP leader insistsAndrew Madden:OpinionElection briefing: It’s battle stations for UUP, but indferent Tories need a nudgeThat seems to hint at support for implementing the decades of reports which say Northern Ireland has too many small hospitals, some of which need to be closed or downgraded to centralise expertise in centres of excellence.But the UUP is not explicit about this.There are other hints of centralising services — “a regionally consistent approach to cancer services across Northern Ireland” with “regional pathways and rapid diagnostic clinics”.The party also proposes greater evening and weekend use of theatres, but hints at the cost by saying it will mean “properly incentivising the move towards a genuine seven day a week health service”.Signicantly, the party says it would ban the use of contract agency workers — but only “once the immediate HSC pressures subside” .Health trusts are sharply criticised, with the UUP saying that for too long “sub-optimal trust performances [have been] tolerated”, something which suggests frustration at what Mr Swann has seen within the system.His solution is a new operationally independent HSC chief executive accountable to a board with political, professional and civic society membership, similar to the Policing Board.On the NI Protocol, the UUP says that “unionists cannot accept an internal border within the United Kingdom. There can be no border in the Irish Sea between Northern Ireland and Great Britain”.That simple commitment seems to prevent the UUP signing up to any revised protocol involving an Irish Sea border.Its tone is dferent to the DUP, talking about wanting to “maintain good relations with the EU”, but the content is similar to that of the ERG — pushing mutual enforcement, with a new north-south body to oversee this. A requirement to label GB goods coming into NI “for UK sale only” would only avoid a new Irish Sea borderit was enforced for all UK products.The party would ban gay conversion therapy, establish a gambling regulator, allocate overdue investment to football stadia, and examine letting private garages do MoT tests.The party opposes a Troubles amnesty and robustly says paramilitaries “need to be put out of business permanently” by focussing on their leaderships and criminal assets. It wants to curb legal aid, due to “the culture of lawfare which has been allowed to develop within our legal system and which has proved extremely lucrative for a number of firms”.The manesto is laden with more spending — new train stops, new busses, new roads, more rates relief for some businesses, spending on city deals,  more police officers, and looking at giving everyone in primary school a free meal.How this would be paid for is unclear. There is no talk of increasing rates. Water charges are ruled out. And giving Stormont more tax powers is also rejected. Changing the status of NI Waterand the Housing Executive to allow them to borrow is about as far as funding proposals go.This is a detailed document, yet many of the proposals are all things to all people – it is pro-business, but also pro-worker pro-grammar schools, but looking to review how academic selection operates, pro-EU, but anti-protocol.None of those things are necessarily contradictory, but in not being clearer about some of the most controversial or unpopular areas, the party is putting off having to take those decisions until after they’ve got the votes.Related topicsUlster Unionist PartyDoug BeattieThe Executive OfficeRobin SwannNI ProtocolMore On Ulster Unionist Party PremiumCouncil concern for future of famous Derry store Austins amid fears it could collapseAndrew MaddenOpinionElection briefing: It’s battle stations for UUP, but indferent Tories need a nudge PremiumJust £k spent as multi-million pound Northern Ireland football stadiums scheme lies idleCarrickfergus murder probe: Woman’s horror at reservoir body find PremiumSam McBrideOpinionDUP gains ground, but overall support drops for ided unionismMost ReadSDLP MP Claire Hanna’s ‘shock’ over proposal by Sinn Fein to abolish her South Belfast seatHaving a laugh:  top office-themed pranks for April Fool’s DayHow to spot the Northern Lights over Northern Ireland tonightRoy Reynolds: Co Antrim murder victim suffered ‘barbaric injuries’, court told‘My baby would still be aliveI’d got proper care at Lagan Valley Hospital’: Grieving mum speaks outTop VideosPlayPolice attend the scene of a serious RTC on the Springfield Road in west Belfast programme, which celebrates its th anniversary this year. Since then, the war in Ukraine has reminded us how fragile our world can be. It has compounded the rising cost of living, and alongside inflationary pressures and the long tail of the pandemic, the tone of the outlook for  and beyond has changed. Credit: Liam McBurneySuzanne BreenTwitterEmailApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailSDLP MP Claire Hanna has spoken of her shock at a Sinn Fein proposal to abolish the constituency of South Belfast.In a submission to the Boundary Commission, the party proposes the constituency is axed with its voters largely ided between two other constituencies — despite South Belfast having more voters than either East or West Belfast.Ms Hanna said Sinn Fein’s proposal “does not make any mathematical sense” and that residents would be stunned it was seeking to abolish Northern Ireland’s most politically erse constituency.Sinn Fein has been contacted for comment.South Belfast currently is the only constituency toMLAs from five dferent parties: SDLP, DUP, Alliance, Sinn Fein and Greens.Ms Hanna said: “Each of Belfast’s four constituencies has a distinct identity, community cohesion, and things they are proud of. South Belfast has for decades been known as a erse, integrated part of the city where people of all political views and none live side-by-side.“Many people chose to settle in South Belfast precisely because of that. This constituency is, and always has been, a shared space.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “It is pluralist in its politics and values, and I think residents would be very disconcerted and concerned at a proposal to break it up and to parcel bits off into other constituencies.”Read MoreTalks need to begin over scrapping mandatory coalition, says Arlene FosterThe rules for the  Boundary Commission review mean each constituency must have an electorate of between , and ,.North Belfastand South Belfastfall within the target range. West Belfastand East Belfastdo not.Ms Hanna lodged her objections to Sinn Fein’s proposal at a meeting with the Boundary Commission last month.“West and East Belfast are below the statutory electoral range by , and , voters respectively,” she said.“The high level of house-building in South Belfast, particularly in the Four Winds and Malone, together with the council’s determination to repopulate the city core, means the number of electors in South Belfast is going to rise further within a parliamentary term.“The Boundary Commission was happy for Northern Ireland to keep all its  seats. In previous proposals in , which were dropped, it had wanted to reduce to  seats, so somewhere would have had to take the fall.“Sinn Fein’s proposal is even more surprising when the Boundary Commission isn’t even looking to lose a seat.”Under Sinn Fein’s plan, Belfast would be reduced from four constituencies to three.East Belfast would remain, absorbing parts of South Belfast, and two new constituencies would be created — North West Belfast and South West Belfast.Ormeau, Rosetta, and Ravenhill would be moved into East Belfast. Malone, Stranmillis, and Finaghy would be put into the new South West Belfast constituency.Demographic trends suggest Sinn Fein would secure both the South West and North West Belfast seats at a Westminster election, with the SDLP losing out. The influx of South Belfast voters to the east of the city would help Alliance unseat the DUP there.In its submission to the Boundary Commission, Michelle O’Neill’s party says: “Sinn Fein believe that too much emphasis is placed in trying to keep Belfast as four-seater constituency which comes at the detriment to the rest of the constituencies.”Under the Boundary Commission’s plan, South Belfast remains largely intact, but gains the rural wards of Drumbo, Saintfield, and Moneyreagh to become South Belfast and Mid Down. Strangford would be renamed Strangford and Quoile.Professor Jon Tonge of the University of Liverpool said the commission’s proposed boundary changes were “fairly minimalist”.“Fermanagh and South Tyrone — very marginal — becomes fractionally more nationalist, which will please Sinn Fein.
